canonical_explanation.text: Food provides nutrients that our body needs. Carbohydrates (rice, bread, roti) give energy. Proteins (milk, eggs, dal) help in growth and repair. Fats (butter, oil, ghee) provide energy and warmth. Vitamins and minerals protect us from diseases and keep us healthy. Water helps in digestion and keeps the body cool. Roughage (fibre from fruits, vegetables) helps in removing waste. A balanced diet includes all nutrients in the right amounts. Digestion begins in the mouth where teeth chew food and saliva mixes with it. The food pipe carries food to the stomach. The stomach churns food with digestive juices. The small intestine absorbs nutrients into the blood. The large intestine absorbs water, and waste is removed from the body. We have four types of teeth: incisors cut food, canines tear food, and premolars and molars grind food. Children have milk teeth that fall out and are replaced by permanent teeth. We should brush our teeth twice a day and avoid eating too many sweets.
rules: Carbohydrates provide energy (rice, bread, roti, potato)
Proteins help in growth and repair (milk, eggs, dal, paneer)
Fats provide energy and keep body warm (butter, oil, ghee)
Vitamins and minerals protect from diseases
Water aids digestion and roughage helps remove waste
A balanced diet includes all nutrients in right amounts
Digestion starts in mouth with teeth and saliva
Food pipe (oesophagus) carries food to stomach
Stomach churns food with digestive juices
Small intestine absorbs nutrients into blood
Large intestine absorbs water, waste is removed
Incisors cut, canines tear, premolars and molars grind food
Milk teeth are replaced by permanent teeth
Brush teeth twice daily, avoid too many sweets

questions.question_text: Which nutrient gives us energy to run and play?
questions.explanation_correct: Carbohydrates are the main source of energy in our body. Foods like rice, bread, and roti give us carbohydrates that our body uses as fuel to run, play, and study.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamins, minerals, and water are important for health but they do not provide energy directly. Carbohydrates from foods like rice and bread are the nutrients that give us energy.

questions.question_text: Which of these foods is rich in proteins?
questions.explanation_correct: Dal (lentils) is rich in proteins. Proteins help our body grow and repair itself. Other protein-rich foods include milk, eggs, paneer, and fish.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice and potato are rich in carbohydrates, not proteins. Sugar provides only energy. Dal is the correct answer because lentils are an excellent source of protein, especially in Indian meals.

questions.question_text: What is the main function of proteins in our body?
questions.explanation_correct: The main function of proteins is to help in the growth and repair of our body. Proteins build our muscles, skin, and other body parts and also repair any damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While proteins play many roles, their main function is growth and repair. Carbohydrates and fats give energy and warmth. Vitamins and minerals help fight germs and diseases.

questions.question_text: Fats help our body to:

options.text: Store energy and keep the body warm

questions.explanation_correct: Fats help our body store energy and keep us warm. When we eat butter, ghee, or oil, the fats are stored in our body and used when we need extra energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fats do not build bones (that is the job of calcium), digest food (that is done by the digestive system), or carry oxygen (that is done by blood). Fats store energy and provide warmth to the body.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a source of carbohydrates?
questions.explanation_correct: Roti is made from wheat flour, which is rich in carbohydrates. Carbohydrates give us the energy we need for daily activities. Rice, bread, and potatoes are also rich in carbohydrates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ghee is a source of fats. Fish and paneer are sources of proteins. Roti, made from wheat, is the correct answer because wheat is rich in carbohydrates that give us energy.

questions.question_text: Rohan is feeling weak and tired after playing. Which type of food should he eat to get quick energy?
questions.explanation_correct: A banana is rich in carbohydrates and provides quick energy. When we feel tired after playing, carbohydrate-rich foods like bananas, biscuits, or glucose water help us regain energy fast.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An egg provides proteins (for growth), butter provides fats (slow energy), and lemon water provides vitamins. For quick energy, carbohydrate-rich foods like bananas are the best choice.

questions.question_text: Meena's mother gives her milk every day. Which nutrient is she mainly getting from milk?
questions.explanation_correct: Milk is rich in proteins and calcium. Proteins help in growth and repair, while calcium makes bones and teeth strong. That is why children are advised to drink milk every day.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While milk does contain some fats and carbohydrates, it is mainly valued for its proteins and calcium. Roughage comes from fruits and vegetables, not milk.

questions.question_text:
Match the following nutrients with their functions:
1. Carbohydrates - (a) Growth and repair
2. Proteins - (b) Protection from diseases
3. Vitamins - (c) Energy

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct matching is: Carbohydrates give energy (1-c), Proteins help in growth and repair (2-a), and Vitamins protect from diseases (3-b). Each nutrient has a specific main function in our body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Carbohydrates = energy, Proteins = growth and repair, Vitamins = protection from diseases. The correct matching is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b.

questions.question_text: True or False: Vitamins and minerals protect our body from diseases.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Vitamins and minerals help protect our body from diseases and keep us healthy. For example, Vitamin C helps fight colds, and iron (a mineral) helps carry oxygen in blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is actually true. Vitamins and minerals are called protective nutrients because they help our body stay healthy and fight diseases.

questions.question_text: Which of the following food items provides BOTH carbohydrates and proteins?
questions.explanation_correct: Rajma (kidney beans) provides both carbohydrates and proteins. Pulses and beans are special because they contain significant amounts of both these nutrients, making them an important part of Indian meals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sugar provides only carbohydrates. Butter and cooking oil provide mainly fats. Rajma is the correct answer because pulses and beans are unique in providing both carbohydrates and proteins.

questions.question_text: Nutrients that help in growth and repair of our body are called ________.
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins help in the growth and repair of our body. They are found in foods like milk, eggs, dal, paneer, and fish. Children need plenty of proteins because they are still growing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbohydrates give energy, fats store energy, and minerals protect from diseases. The nutrient that helps in growth and repair is protein.

questions.question_text: A balanced diet means eating:

options.text: All types of nutrients in the right amounts

questions.explanation_correct: A balanced diet contains all types of nutrients such as carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, water, and roughage in the right amounts. This ensures our body gets everything it needs to stay healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eating only one type of food is not a balanced diet. A balanced diet must include all nutrients in the right proportions, not just one food group.

questions.question_text: Which meal is closest to a balanced diet?

options.text: Rice, dal, vegetable sabzi, curd, and a fruit

questions.explanation_correct: A meal with rice (carbohydrates), dal (proteins), vegetable sabzi (vitamins, minerals, roughage), curd (proteins, calcium), and fruit (vitamins) is closest to a balanced diet because it includes all food groups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only rice and dal, chips with cold drink, or only bread and butter do not contain all food groups. A balanced diet needs carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, and roughage together.

questions.question_text: Priya eats only chips and biscuits every day. What problem might she face?

options.text: She may fall sick because her diet is not balanced

questions.explanation_correct: If Priya eats only chips and biscuits, she will not get all the nutrients her body needs. This is not a balanced diet, and she may become weak, fall sick often, and not grow properly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eating only junk food like chips and biscuits does not make you strong or tall. It leads to health problems because the body does not get the proteins, vitamins, and minerals it needs.

questions.question_text: Aman's lunch has roti, paneer curry, salad, and buttermilk. Which nutrient is MISSING from his meal?

options.text: A fruit for extra vitamins and roughage

questions.explanation_correct: Aman's meal has roti (carbohydrates), paneer (proteins and fats), salad (vitamins, minerals), and buttermilk (proteins, calcium). Adding a fruit would give extra vitamins and roughage to make it even more balanced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The meal already has carbohydrates (roti), proteins (paneer, buttermilk), and vitamins (salad). Adding a fruit would provide additional vitamins and fibre to complete the balanced diet.

questions.question_text: Why is roughage (fibre) important in our diet even though it does not give us energy or nutrients?

options.text: It helps in removing waste from the body and prevents constipation

questions.explanation_correct: Roughage (fibre) is important because it helps the large intestine push out waste from the body. Without enough roughage, a person can get constipation. Fruits, vegetables, and whole grains are good sources of roughage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roughage does not make food taste better, strengthen bones, or help with sleep. Its main function is to help in the smooth removal of waste from the body and prevent constipation.

questions.question_text: True or False: Eating only one type of food every day is a balanced diet.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. A balanced diet must include many different types of foods so that we get all nutrients. Eating only one type of food will cause our body to miss important nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. A balanced diet requires variety, including carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, water, and roughage from different food sources.

questions.question_text:
Arrange the following in the order they appear from bottom to top in a food pyramid:
(i) Fats and sweets (ii) Grains and cereals (iii) Fruits and vegetables (iv) Milk, meat, and pulses
questions.explanation_correct: In a food pyramid, the bottom has grains and cereals (eat most), then fruits and vegetables, then milk/meat/pulses, and fats and sweets at the top (eat least). So the order from bottom to top is (ii), (iii), (iv), (i).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The food pyramid shows we should eat the most of grains (bottom) and the least of fats and sweets (top). The correct order from bottom to top is: grains, fruits and vegetables, milk/meat/pulses, fats and sweets.

questions.question_text: Where does digestion start in our body?
questions.explanation_correct: Digestion starts in the mouth. When we eat, our teeth chew the food into small pieces and saliva mixes with the food to begin breaking it down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although the stomach and intestines are important for digestion, the process actually begins in the mouth where teeth chew the food and saliva starts breaking it down.

questions.question_text: What is the function of the food pipe (oesophagus)?

options.text: It carries food from the mouth to the stomach

questions.explanation_correct: The food pipe (oesophagus) is a tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach. It pushes food down using wave-like movements, even if you are standing upside down!
questions.explanation_incorrect: The food pipe does not digest food (that happens in the stomach), absorb nutrients (that happens in the small intestine), or remove waste (that happens in the large intestine). It simply carries food from the mouth to the stomach.

questions.question_text: What happens to food in the stomach?

options.text: It is churned and mixed with digestive juices

questions.explanation_correct: In the stomach, food is churned (mixed around) and mixed with digestive juices. This helps break the food into even smaller pieces so that nutrients can be absorbed later in the small intestine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food is not chewed again in the stomach (chewing happens only in the mouth). Nutrient absorption happens in the small intestine, and water absorption happens in the large intestine. The stomach churns food and mixes it with digestive juices.

questions.question_text: Which organ absorbs nutrients from digested food into the blood?
questions.explanation_correct: The small intestine absorbs nutrients from digested food into the blood. The blood then carries these nutrients to all parts of the body where they are used for energy, growth, and repair.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mouth chews food, the food pipe carries it to the stomach, and the stomach churns it. It is the small intestine that absorbs the nutrients from the digested food into the blood.

questions.question_text: Why do we need to chew our food well before swallowing?

options.text: Because food tastes better when chewed
Because smaller pieces are easier to digest
Because it makes the food hot
Because it removes germs from food

questions.explanation_correct: We need to chew food well because smaller pieces are easier for the stomach and intestines to digest. When food is chewed into small pieces and mixed with saliva, digestion becomes faster and smoother.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While chewed food may taste better, the main reason for chewing well is that smaller pieces are much easier for the digestive system to break down. Chewing does not make food hot or remove germs.

questions.question_text: The ________ absorbs water from the leftover food and forms waste.
questions.explanation_correct: The large intestine absorbs water from the leftover food and forms solid waste. This waste is then removed from the body. The large intestine is the last major organ in the digestive system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The small intestine absorbs nutrients, the stomach churns food, and the food pipe carries food. It is the large intestine that absorbs water from leftover food and forms waste.

questions.question_text: Put the digestive organs in the correct order that food travels through them:

options.text: Mouth → Stomach → Food pipe → Small intestine → Large intestine
Mouth → Food pipe → Stomach → Small intestine → Large intestine
Mouth → Food pipe → Small intestine → Stomach → Large intestine
Mouth → Large intestine → Stomach → Food pipe → Small intestine

questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Mouth (chewing and saliva) → Food pipe (carries food down) → Stomach (churns with juices) → Small intestine (absorbs nutrients) → Large intestine (absorbs water, removes waste).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food first enters the mouth, then travels through the food pipe to the stomach, then to the small intestine, and finally to the large intestine. The correct order is Mouth → Food pipe → Stomach → Small intestine → Large intestine.

questions.question_text: Saliva in the mouth helps in digestion by:

options.text: Making food soft and wet, and starting to break down starch

questions.explanation_correct: Saliva makes the food soft and wet so it can slide easily through the food pipe. It also starts breaking down starch (a type of carbohydrate) into simpler forms. This is why if you chew roti for a long time, it starts tasting slightly sweet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saliva does not make food hard, remove germs, or add vitamins. Its job is to make food soft and wet for easy swallowing and to begin the breakdown of starch in the food.

questions.question_text: What would happen if the small intestine did not work properly?

options.text: Food would not reach the stomach
The body would not get nutrients from food

questions.explanation_correct: If the small intestine did not work properly, nutrients from digested food could not be absorbed into the blood. This means the body would not get the nutrition it needs, even if we eat food. A person would become weak and sick.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chewing happens in the mouth, and the food pipe carries food to the stomach. The small intestine's job is to absorb nutrients. Without it working, the body would not receive any nutrients from the food we eat.

questions.question_text: True or False: The stomach is the organ where nutrients are absorbed into the blood.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The stomach churns food and mixes it with digestive juices, but nutrients are absorbed into the blood in the small intestine, not the stomach.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. The stomach's main job is to churn food and mix it with digestive juices. Nutrient absorption happens in the small intestine.

questions.question_text: Which type of teeth do we use to cut food?
questions.explanation_correct: Incisors are the flat, sharp front teeth that we use to cut and bite food. When you take a bite of an apple, you use your incisors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Canines are the pointed teeth used for tearing food. Molars and premolars are the broad teeth at the back used for grinding food. Incisors are the front teeth that cut and bite food.

questions.question_text: Canine teeth are used for:
questions.explanation_correct: Canine teeth are the pointed teeth on either side of the incisors. They are used for tearing food, like when you tear a piece of chapati or pull meat from a bone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cutting is done by incisors, grinding by molars and premolars, and mixing with saliva is not done by teeth. Canines are the pointed teeth used specifically for tearing food.

questions.question_text: Which teeth are used for grinding and crushing food?
questions.explanation_correct: Molars and premolars are the big, flat teeth at the back of the mouth. They have a broad surface that is perfect for grinding and crushing food into very small pieces before swallowing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Incisors cut food and canines tear food. It is the molars and premolars at the back of the mouth that grind and crush food. Not all teeth do the same job.

questions.question_text: When you bite into a sugarcane, which teeth do you use first?
questions.explanation_correct: When you bite into sugarcane, you first use your incisors (front teeth) to cut into it. Then you use your molars and premolars to chew and crush the sugarcane to extract the juice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Molars, premolars, and canines are not the first teeth used when biting. Incisors, being the front cutting teeth, are always used first when we take a bite of anything.

questions.question_text: What are the first set of teeth that children get called?
questions.explanation_correct: The first set of teeth that children get are called milk teeth (also called baby teeth). Children usually have 20 milk teeth. These start falling out around age 6-7 and are replaced by permanent teeth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Permanent teeth are the second set of teeth that replace milk teeth. Wisdom teeth come much later in life. The first set of teeth in children are called milk teeth or baby teeth.

questions.question_text: What should you do to keep your teeth healthy?

options.text: Eat lots of chocolates and sweets
Brush your teeth twice a day and eat less sugar

questions.explanation_correct: To keep teeth healthy, you should brush twice a day (morning and night), eat fewer sweets and sugary foods, eat calcium-rich foods like milk and cheese, and visit the dentist regularly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eating lots of sweets causes tooth decay. Not brushing or brushing only once a week lets germs build up on teeth. Brushing twice daily and eating less sugar is the best way to care for your teeth.

questions.question_text: True or False: Milk teeth fall out and are replaced by permanent teeth.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Children have 20 milk teeth that begin to fall out around age 6-7. They are replaced by 32 permanent teeth that are meant to last a lifetime.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is actually true. Milk teeth do fall out naturally and are replaced by a second set called permanent teeth.

questions.question_text:
Match the type of tooth with its function:
1. Incisors - (a) Grinding
2. Canines - (b) Cutting
3. Molars - (c) Tearing

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Incisors cut food (1-b), Canines tear food (2-c), and Molars grind food (3-a). Each type of tooth has a special shape that helps it do its specific job.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Incisors are flat and sharp for cutting (like scissors), Canines are pointed for tearing, and Molars are broad for grinding. The correct matching is 1-b, 2-c, 3-a.

questions.question_text: Raj's grandmother told him to eat oranges and lemons. Which nutrient is she mainly trying to give him?
questions.explanation_correct: Oranges and lemons are citrus fruits that are very rich in Vitamin C. Vitamin C helps protect us from colds and other infections and keeps our skin and gums healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oranges and lemons are not significant sources of proteins, fats, or carbohydrates. They are known for being rich in Vitamin C, which protects us from diseases and keeps us healthy.

questions.question_text: A child who does not eat enough fruits and vegetables may lack which nutrients?
questions.explanation_correct: Fruits and vegetables are the main sources of vitamins, minerals, and roughage (fibre) in our diet. A child who does not eat them may become weak, fall sick easily, and have digestion problems due to lack of fibre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbohydrates come mainly from grains, fats from oils and butter, and proteins from dal and milk. Fruits and vegetables are most important for vitamins, minerals, and roughage.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of water in our body?
questions.explanation_correct: Water does not provide energy to run. Energy comes from carbohydrates and fats. Water helps in digestion, keeps the body cool through sweating, and helps carry nutrients in the blood to all body parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water helps in digestion, keeps the body cool, and carries nutrients in blood. However, it does not provide energy. Energy comes from the food we eat, especially carbohydrates and fats.

questions.question_text: The liquid in our mouth that helps soften food and start digestion is called ________.
questions.explanation_correct: Saliva is the liquid produced in our mouth that helps soften food, make it wet for easy swallowing, and starts breaking down starch. Our mouth makes saliva all day, especially when we eat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While we do drink water, the liquid naturally produced in the mouth that helps with digestion is called saliva. Blood and juice are not produced in the mouth for digestion.

questions.question_text: During winter, Anita's mother gives her ghee with roti. Why is this helpful in winter?

options.text: Ghee has vitamins that fight cold
Ghee has fats that help keep the body warm

questions.explanation_correct: Ghee is rich in fats. Fats help store energy and keep the body warm. During winter, eating foods rich in fats like ghee helps the body produce more heat and stay warm in cold weather.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ghee is mainly a source of fats, not vitamins, proteins, or carbohydrates. Fats keep the body warm, which is why eating ghee in winter is considered helpful in Indian households.

questions.question_text: Which statement about the digestive system is CORRECT?

options.text: The large intestine absorbs nutrients into blood
The stomach absorbs water from food
The small intestine is where most nutrients are absorbed

questions.explanation_correct: The small intestine is where most nutrients from digested food are absorbed into the blood. It is the longest part of the digestive system and has a large surface area for absorbing nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The large intestine absorbs water (not nutrients). The stomach churns food (not absorbs water). The food pipe just carries food (not digests it). The small intestine is the main organ for nutrient absorption.

questions.question_text: True or False: Junk food like chips, pizza, and cold drinks is part of a balanced diet.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Junk food like chips, pizza, and cold drinks are high in fats, salt, and sugar but low in vitamins, minerals, and roughage. Eating too much junk food is not healthy and is not part of a balanced diet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Junk food does not provide the range of nutrients our body needs. A balanced diet includes grains, fruits, vegetables, proteins, and dairy, not junk food.

questions.question_text: How many milk teeth does a child usually have?
questions.explanation_correct: A child usually has 20 milk teeth. These include 8 incisors, 4 canines, and 8 molars. Later, these milk teeth fall out and are replaced by 32 permanent teeth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A child does not have 10, 28, or 32 milk teeth. Children have 20 milk teeth. Adults have 32 permanent teeth. This is an important difference to remember.

questions.question_text: Which group of foods is rich in fats?
questions.explanation_correct: Butter, ghee, nuts, and oil are all rich in fats. Fats provide energy, keep the body warm, and help absorb certain vitamins. We should eat fats in moderate amounts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice, wheat, and potato are rich in carbohydrates. Oranges, guavas, and lemons are rich in vitamins. Dal, eggs, and fish are rich in proteins. Butter, ghee, nuts, and oil are the fat-rich foods.

questions.question_text: A diet that contains all nutrients in the right amounts is called a ________ diet.
questions.explanation_correct: A balanced diet is one that contains all nutrients - carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, water, and roughage - in the right amounts. It keeps our body healthy and helps us grow properly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A junk diet is unhealthy, a protein diet has only proteins, and a heavy diet just means eating too much. The correct term for a diet with all nutrients in the right amounts is a balanced diet.

questions.question_text: After eating lunch, where is the food FIRST sent from your mouth?

options.text: Through the food pipe to the stomach
Through the blood to all body parts

questions.explanation_correct: After chewing in the mouth, food travels through the food pipe (oesophagus) to reach the stomach. The food pipe is a tube that connects the mouth to the stomach.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food does not go directly to the stomach or small intestine. It must first pass through the food pipe, which is the tube connecting the mouth to the stomach.

questions.question_text: Sara is 8 years old and her front tooth has fallen out. What will happen next?

options.text: A permanent tooth will grow in its place
She needs to see a doctor immediately

questions.explanation_correct: When a milk tooth falls out, a permanent tooth grows in its place. This is a natural process that happens to all children between ages 6-12. Sara's permanent tooth will grow soon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is normal for children to lose their milk teeth. A new permanent tooth will grow in its place. This is not a medical emergency, and another milk tooth will not grow. Permanent teeth replace milk teeth.

questions.question_text: Why do growing children need more proteins in their diet compared to adults?

options.text: Because children's bodies are growing and need proteins for building new cells and tissues
Because children do not need vitamins

questions.explanation_correct: Growing children need more proteins because their bodies are actively building new cells, muscles, and tissues. Proteins are the building blocks of the body, and since children are growing, they need more of these building blocks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy comes from carbohydrates, not proteins. The reason children need more proteins is that their bodies are growing rapidly, and proteins are needed to build new muscles, bones, and other body parts.

questions.question_text: Which of these is the LONGEST organ in the digestive system?
questions.explanation_correct: The small intestine is the longest organ in the digestive system, about 6-7 metres long! Despite its name, it is called 'small' because it is narrow (thin), not because of its length. Its length helps it absorb maximum nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although it is called 'small', the small intestine is actually the longest part of the digestive system. The word 'small' refers to its width (it is narrow), not its length. It needs to be long to absorb all the nutrients from food.
